questions.question_text: During a post-incident review, it was determined that a known vulnerability was exploited in order to gain access to a system. The vulnerability was patched as part of the remediation on the offending system. Which of the following should be done NEXT?

choices.C: Install patches an all existing systems.
choices.A: Scan to determine whether the vulnerability is present on other systems.
choices.D: Report the root cause of the vulnerability to senior management.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I'm going with A. I get it is a known vulnerability. But option C states " Install patches an all existing systems." The ALL EXISTING SYSTEMS seems excessive because we don't know what all the systems are. Assuming everything is the same is illogical as almost all businesses make use of several different OS, versions, etc... so installing a patch on "ALL EXISITNG SYSTMES" with out scanning to see which ones actually need the patch first seems like a mistake and like it could interrupt the work environment. This is why I pick option A.

comments.content:
Agreed! To me, C happens after A. Fire up Nessus/OpenVas/whatever and check other systems for the existence of this vulnerability. Patch all systems that have the vulnerability present.

Do NOT apply patch to a system that doesn't have it. You never know if it could have an adverse effect to the OS.

discussion.content: Here is what you all are missing if you think that C is correct... Patching all existing systems may break certain functions and render some software unusable for a specific business purpose. That is why a risk assessment needs to be done to determine if patching is the right thing to do in light of the business needs or the organization. Once you scan and find the vulnerability on other systems, it is up to Management to determine whether it should be patched pursuant to their business needs.
A could be the answer for CISM, but in reality it is a known vulnerability, there is no need but to patch it by default.

questions.question_text: During an internal compliance review, the review team discovers that a critical legacy application is unable to meet the organization's mandatory security requirements. Which of the following should be done FIRST?

discussion.content: I believe it is C if the review team discovered noncompliance and likely documented it in the report and risk register...

Selected Answer: A
update the risk register first and then track it on regular intervals.

Selected Answer: A
Update the risk register first. This way you can better understand the risk and choose how to treat the risk (like with compensating controls).

comments.content: In the context of the question, the order should be A->C->D.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Update the risk register.

Updating the risk register is the initial action to document and track the identified risk associated with the critical legacy application. This involves recording the non-compliance with mandatory security requirements and assessing the potential impact and likelihood of the risk. Once the risk is documented, the organization can then proceed to determine the most appropriate risk treatment strategy.

While options like recommending taking the application out of service (Option B), implementing compensating controls (Option C), and monitoring the application until it can be replaced (Option D) are potential risk treatment strategies, updating the risk register is the foundational step in the risk management process. It ensures that the organization has a clear record of the identified risk and can make informed decisions on how to address it.

Selected Answer: C
C. Implement compensating controls.
